This thing is a 3D replica of a bas-relief that is at the Bulgarian Cultural Institute in Paris (France) where I learned bulgarian during 3 years (and that I'm still learning).

Cette plaque commémorative se trouve apposée au mur à coté de l'entrée de l'Institut Culturel Bulgare à Paris.

Гробът на Хисто Ботев който се намира в Българен Културен Институт в столицата Париж (Франция).

The replica is 5cm long and has two small holes on its right side (left side when looking at it) that allows to glue a small piece of 1.75mm diameter filament as a hook to use it as a keychain if you want.

More about Christo Botev : https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hristo_Botev
Bulgarian Cultural Institute's website : http://www.ccbulgarie.com/

Enjoy !
Всичко хубаво!

http://www.spacymen.com/

PS : I want to thank my friend Stephen for sending me additional photos and my bulgarian teacher fom the Institute for her patience and her professionalism.

Printer:

BfB3000

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm layer thickness

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The Bulgarian Cultural Institute in Paris is a great place to learn the bulgarian language and culture. It' also a place where you can see exhibitions of bulgarian artists and listen to some concerts.
http://www.ccbulgarie.com/

If you want to use it as a keychain, simply glue a small piece of 1.75mm diameter as a hook in the small holes that are on the side.
If you printed it in ABS you can glue it with aceton.
Easy to print, for Spotlight-Lamps

This is my take on the fidget spinners. I put the bearings a bit closer together than most so the 3 bearing spinner can fit in smaller hands. I've also included insertion and removal tools for the bearings which are handy for popping in and out 608 sized bearings. I've added a few additional versions with increased bearing diameters in case the fit is too tight. The files are named with the additional mm size added from 0.1mm - 0.4mm

You can access the Fusion 360 designs here:

  • 2-6 bearing: http://a360.co/2qfLZ6z
  • 7 bearing: http://a360.co/2qeDxRM
  • Cap: http://a360.co/2qN95AT

comments.text: I've uploaded versions with increased diameter bearing holes in case anyone was having trouble with cracking.
comments.author: Shinns

comments.text: Any chance I can get the autodesk file for the 3 bearing or others?
comments.author: tjeagle

comments.text: I posted a link to the cap and the 7 bearing spinner.  The other file is for the 2 to 6 bearing spinner, just check out the arm_count property on the model.  You may have to open up the sweep feature and re-select the edge.  Good luck!
comments.author: tjeagle

comments.text: How good is the one with 7 bearings? I've been designing one but my printer stops printing it half way there.
comments.author: MrAraz

comments.text: I only got one to work without cracking. It was very heavy, but it still fits nicely in a pocket and makes some really cool patterns when spinning due to the light reflecting off of all the bearings (assuming they are shiny). Balances really well too. Wish I would have better luck getting them to hold bearings without cracking
comments.author: MrAraz

comments.text: I've posted additional versions of the 4 bearing spinner with a +0.2mm and +0.4mm OD increase.  Let me know if either of these work for you and I can generate versions for the rest of them.
comments.author: chrisbloom7

comments.text: @Shinns - Sending you a message about the results

comments.text: Oh, cool, thanks! I'll give them a try today
comments.author: Shinns

comments.text:
Printed it right away and it broke apart, when i pressed in the bearings.
I then scaled it to 102% and now ist just a perfect fit.
comments.author: DerEd95

comments.text: Would you mind sharing your extrusion and speed settings? I get a lot of requests for these but haven't been able to get a batch printed that doesn't crack. Are you using PLA?
comments.author: DerEd95

comments.text: That one i did was 102% scaled, 215/60°C at 60mm/s using PLA
comments.author: chrisbloom7

comments.text: If it doesn't fit I usually take a knife that fits in the hole and carve it out until the bearing fits.
comments.author: DerEd95

comments.text: This may be a dumb question but how do the insertion and removal tools work?
comments.author: ReturnZero

comments.text: The bearing fits onto the insertion tool and helps you evenly press on the bearing with pliers, clamps, etc. without marring the bearing.  The removal tool is just a ring that's sized so you can have something to push against if you want to punch the bearing out.
comments.author: ReturnZero

comments.text: That makes sense. Thanks!
comments.author: Shinns

comments.text: I'm having a lot of trouble dialing the sizing. At 101.25% and below the middle is perfect but the outside holes are too tight and the print cracks, and at 101.50% scale the outside holes are perfect but the inside is too loose and the bearing slips out. (No, I haven't tried 101.375% yet.) I've tried with 30% fill (hoping the empty space would allow for some give) and 100% fill (hoping it would add to the material strength), but that doesn't seem to matter. Any tips? I'm using a vice to insert the bearings, going nice and slow. This is with PLA, and I've tried with multiple spools of filament.
comments.author: chrisbloom7

comments.text: I tried it at 101.38% scale (note that I'm only scaling the X and Y dimensions, Z is still at 100%) but it still cracked when putting the outside bearings in. I'm using standard skate bearings - some Yellow Jackets, some Bones Reds, some generic 608s. They work fine in other spinner prints. I've been mainly testing with the 5-bearing print, but I also had issues with every other design in this print with the exception of the 7-bearing.
comments.author: chrisbloom7

comments.text: Hmm... Instead of adjusting the scale of the part you may want to try adjusting your extrusion multiplier.  Have you tried inserting the bearings from either side as well?  Sometimes the lower layers may be squished a bit more depending on your starting z-height.  I also use the bearing insertion tool and a C-clamp to get the bearings in.  I'll throw the fusion360 files up later today if you want to adjust things yourself.
comments.author: chrisbloom7

comments.text: Thanks for the tips. My extrusion multiplier is currently at 1.0, I'll try reducing it slightly the next print.
comments.author: Shinns

comments.text: Here's the Fusion 360 file if you want to mess with the dimensions yourself: http://a360.co/2qfLZ6z
comments.author: Shinns

comments.text: Did you use exact bearing dimensions when designing? Should we apply scaling before printing?
comments.author: kerembyl

comments.text: I've posted additional versions of the 4 bearing spinner with a +0.2mm and +0.4mm OD increase.  Let me know if either of these work for you and I can generate versions for the rest of them.
comments.author: kerembyl

comments.text: Yes, the holes are exactly the OD of the bearings.  The fit is very snug on my printer but you may have better luck scaling up or down depending on your printer calibration. Over time the bearings can get a bit loose so I recommend running a thin bead of superglue around the edge of the bearing after it's been inserted.

title: Small size, big performance extruding machine !

description.text:
Warning:
This extruder after many month of good services has been superseded by a newer design, a bit lighter more compact using Nema 14 motor and gears used in RC cars. The concept is the same though. Can be seen here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2594693
I keep it here to show what can be done and inspire knowledgeable people to design their own.

Here is a video of a print (20mm test cube Feed pushed to 300%,180mm/s). REAL SPEED !
https://vimeo.com/251363819

I do not provide parts list and detailed instructions because I used parts scavenged from old printers and not readily available.
One can adapt to what they can find.
Now once I find a reliable source of ad hoc parts, I may complete the description.
Overall size could be reduced provided smaller, different gears are used but what is important is reduced weight, reduced GC to X:Z plane, reduced filament travel, reduced distance from the X axis, reduced distance to the hot end tip.

The Titan extruders are the ONLY one that compare. Yet as E3D has to stay compatible with older hot end/mount this one is a bit better as it is "tailor made". So if you can't adapt, go with E3D, about the only one's who seem to know how to design extruder/hot end in the hobby category.

One other thing though, the hobbed gear and idler are of my own, not seen anywhere and I don't want some "vendors" to copy them and make money from it. So adapt to your favorite hobbed gear and idler.

Want to run fast ? Loose weight ! Same here.

The original MK8 supplied by Geeetech is an assembly of poorly designed parts. Too bulky where it shouldn't, too many parts and therefore too many screws to hold them together. and it weights like a dead donkey (more than 500g anyway!) See last picture of parts I thrown away.
Bowden ? No. Besides plenty of hot end fed by bowden extruder are as heavy because of all the gimmicks added (many fans, improper bearings, sensors, too bulky ...)
Flexibe drive ? May be ? Not now anyway.

So at the end, I decided for a classic approach but reducing parts, size, weight etc...

One of the issue now is the Y table weight. which condemns the Prusa for higher performance. Only the print head should move. This is an other project.

I had a PM42 stepper 9 cm.N @ .6A (equivalent to a NEMA14) and a collection of gears from old laser printers that fit my requirements. Motor gear m 0.5 ,17t, hobbed gear 82t, ratio 4.824 giving a torque of about 43 cm.N comparable to what I got from my direct drive NEMA17. These PM steppers have only 48 steps but this is not a problem.
I determined that with my own hobbed gear 12 cm.N is enough for PLA (about 10 N to push the filament). So plenty of safety margin (about 36N push force, hobbed gear won't give up before 40N). Fact is, I set the current to 0.4A and all works fine with PLA, IGUS, ABS, PETG, Nylon. It is better to have the the motor stalls than strip the filament.
I included the two flanges. Up to you to adapt to the gear and motor you can get.
Note I use two bearings 5X11X4 for the idler and hobbed gear side, an Igus bushing I made for the other.
So here are the specs achieved so far:

  • 1.75mm filament. Any kind (flexible too !). Fully guided filament in PTFE and metal.
  • print speed 120mm/s, 180mm/s still OK but limited by other thing (part cooling, Y table ...)
  • only 220g. 270g total X moving mass with the X carriage (3D printed and with my own Igu bushings) (less than half the MK8 plus original carriage)
  • full metal hot end 280° limited in fact by the NTC. Anyway enough for current filaments.
  • the nozzle is 28 mm from to the X plane and 10 mm from the Z plane minimizing the hang out.
  • Center of Gravity very close to the said planes, minimizing the moment arm.
  • Motor can be mounted at top, bottom or even side.
  • Backlash can be minimized by moving the motor..
  • 6 mm from the hobbed gear to hot end funnel, 50 to the nozzle tip. Filament fully guided.
  • One M4 butterfly nut to attach to the X carriage. The mounting bracket is a 10mm square Al bar as shown. It matches a square hole in the carriage.
  • One M3 screw to remove the hot end 6mm flanged smooth tube. Zero is kept.
  • The hot end heat sink can be mounted vertically or horizontaly. In the latter case it is 10mm taller but the air flow can be directed towards the motor. As seen in the video.
  • Easy to load/unload filament. No lever. Just turn on the hot end, introduce the filament then run the extruder. You can also use the big gear to turn the hobbed gear. The filament is fully guided.
    .
    I didn't use printed gears because you simply can't get the correct quality in a small size.
    Here I needed a reduction of about 5 that can be achieved easily with just 2 standard gears. No need for fancy system (worm, planetary ....) that often have backlash you can't easily eliminate..

I didn't use GT2 belt and pulleys because of the bulk and weight.
Belt and pulley have the advantage of no backlash therefore I am looking to use small belts 1mm pitch 3mm wide and 2 pulleys are enough, just a matter to procure them easily at a decent cost.
So later I hope ?

A NEMA 14 or pancake Nema17 should provide enough torque and help shed about 40g. Higher gear ratio to use smaller motor (PM35, PM20) will certainly not provide the required torque and no much further gain. Plus more play, friction and the motor may not be fast enough to retract quickly.

A servo DC motor would be the next step to really reduce weight and size, provide accurate filament delivery but this is an other story.

.
Note: The second picture is of an earlier extruder I made to replace the horrendous MK8. Already a big improvement. It is for comparison. It is simpler, direct drive, Nema17 40mm, same ease of use and attachment, same push force, just too heavy for me. Original Geetech hot end limited to less than 250° because of the PTFE tube inside. I only used PLA at the time. No fan needed, the big heatsink shown is sufficient. The head moves fast enough :). It is even lighter and smaller than he Wade designs that seems to have much popularity here. I fail to understand why as it is complex,clumsy to use. In a word, outdated.

title: Wire Shelf Keyboard Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This print is for people that use wire shelves to hold computer equipment and don't have space for a keyboard. It allows a keyboard to be constantly accessible without taking up any shelf space.

author: greyhawk01

title: Filament Runout Sensor for Scalar 3D Printers

description.text:
Description

This plastic part is a Filament Sensor Module for Scalar 3D printer.
It allows to detect the end of filament and trigger a filament change on firmware side.

Updates

  • 2017.04.02 - Minor fix, the button could sometimes get stuck

Compatibility

  • Compatible with both 1.75 and 3mm filament
  • This is compatible with Marlin RC8 firmware.
  • Just un-comment the runout sensor section on the firmware (near line 776)

Stuff needed

All you need is a mechanical switch with a roller at the end such as this one:
http://3dmodularsystems.com/en/electronic/74-micro-switch-end-stop-with-roller-for-3d-printers.html

Wiring

On ramps board you need to connect one end of the switch to the last servo pins (SERVO3_PIN).
One wire is to be connected to the Signal pin and the other wire is to be connected to the ground pin.

3D Modular Systems
Evolutive 3D Printers

You enjoy it and want to help us with a donation: https://www.paypal.me/3DMS

remixed_from.author: galile0
remixed_from.title: Recycled CD Cases: Doll's House // Toy Shelves

description.text:
With a small bit of printed plastic you can turn your old CD cases into a tower of light. Use the connectors to form either squares or pentagons then stack them as high as you have cases. If you run out you can buy more albums, throw away the CDs and continue stacking. With these decorative lamps, the cases may have more value than the music!

Rotate each layer so that the square or pentagon fits in the groove created by the connectors below. In other words, each CD case layer should rest directly on top of the cases in the previous layer, it should not rest on the connectors. This will maintain level and add greatly to stability. You may have to jiggle the layer box to get it to fit in between the connectors.

To reduce glare but still let light through I cut recycled office paper to place in each CD case. If your case has a clear insert you can place the paper under that, otherwise you may wish to tape the corners. Remove any black or white inserts since they will completely block the light.

The pentagon example uses a multi-color LED strip, easily found on E-bay, run up through the bottom of the lamp. You can secure it to the top in many ways. I used a wooden skewer and a clothespin. The square was stacked up over the base of an old floor lamp and has four candelabra sized LEDs lighting it. I've ordered an LED Sound Sensor to turn the tower into a syncopated spire but it has not arrived yet. Thanks to Galile0 and the CD case doll house for the original inspiration.

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from 12" x 9" (Arch A sheet size) - four of these would fit within an (Arch C) 24" x 18" sheet size or across the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG file that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

remixed_from.title: 30mm Minimal Fan Guard: MP Select Mini

description.text:
So I had this very simple fan guard I downloaded from Thingiverse, I used it on mu hot end.
I thought I clown around with it. I made it blank and then tried holes, slots, whatever, but it wasn't "fun" enough.. Then I found the Wings of Freedom" crest from the manga/anime "Attack on Titan" or 進撃の巨人 as some like to call it.
Shingeki no Kyojin (the romanji for that previou kanji) actually translates to something like attacking Titans or perhaps war with the Titans. I know, I'm showing off. I actually only know about 6 words in Japanese. I do however know how to use Wikipedia.
Be that as it may (or "demo" in Japanese).I combined the two printer files into a sort of Attack on Titan fan guard. Haven't printed it out yet so please refrain from cussin' me out when it fails miserably. I don't even know if air will pass through it, so maybe using it on your hot end is not a good idea.

description.text:
A filament roll holder with an adjustable mounting bracket, mountable on the top 2020 bar of your printer.
Included is a center rod which will lock in place; I put a handful of bearings on it for friction-free spinning (the other end of the rod is left open for that), but they're not required.

The default STL is designed around a filament roll with a 60mm diameter hole and a total diameter of 200mm; all of the rolls I've used are well below that.

Customize-able: you can change the mounting piece offset to align the roll nicely with your extruder. For full control, download the .scad; it's fairly well commented.

Update 2017-03-02
Added a handle to the rod, making it much easier to lift & remove it while using your other hand is pre-occupied with the filament roll.
Dab a bit of hotglue on the rod to keep the bearings in for even more Quality of Life.

Pst! Hey! This is my first design, so if you do use this, it'd be neat if you could upload some pics!

TEVO Tarantula i3

title: Rack and Pinion Hand Cranked Drive

description.text:
Rack and Pinion Hand Cranked Drive

180 degrees of rotation equals 1-3/4 of liner travel. The rack can be elongated to achieve the desired about of travel. Its pretty small, 1-5/8" x 3" lg. I would think that it would be scalable but I have not tried. There is a slot on the end of the gear rack that will hold a M3 nut so you can mount what ever you would like to the end of the rack.

The prints are pretty easy to make, no supports required. All my pars went together the first time with no sanding. After printing all six pieces place the rack and the pinion in the LH housing. Then snap on the RH housing on to the LH housing. Next put the handle into the pinon and snap the swivel onto the handle. If you wish the assembly stay together permanently you can superglue the two housing together and superglue the handle into the pinion, but mine stayed together without superglue.

The next version will operate with a micro hobby servo.

Video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hN7Va3Aydgo

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Supports:

No

Notes:

You will have to rotate the STL's so they are in the proper orientation for printing. The orientation should be pretty self explanatory.

description.text:
After starting my journey into 3D printing, I amassed a few tools that I always kept by the printer. These wound up cluttering my bench, so I made a modular tool storage system that would keep my tools nearby but out of the way.

It was also my first attempt at designing my own objects using OnShape, so it was a valuable learning experience too. I made several iterations, each (hopefully) improving upon the previous.

Here is my end-result.

No special print settings required. Given the wide base, you won't need rafts, brims, or supports. You can print at whatever layer height you wish, but I used 0.2 so that the text on the top of each block would still have some definition. You can use whatever infill you'd like, I used 15% so that it could stand up to some mild abuse.

The base of each module is lightly chamfered, which should help with removal from the print bed.

So...I want to make curios for each of the grandchildren. I made nameplates, but that's kind of lame, if you get my drift. What to do.
I created a simple box with a lid and paneled sides and top. For each kid I added something they liked and their name. In this case I made one based on my grand dauhters but generic. For the unicorn I used a medallion I found here on Thingiverse and modified it by removing the hanger thingy.
The box is only 100mm square, but maybe it can be used for that small something kids hold precious.

title: MP Select Mini NEMA 17 z-axis motor adapter plate

description.text:
This adapter plate was designed to adapt a NEMA 17 stepper to the z-axis on the MP Select Mini printer and keeps the new motor shaft in the correct spot reference the old motor. I used a stepper with integrated 8mm lead screw but you could use a motor/leadscrew/coupler. The leadscrew nut was a perfect fit and bolts straight on in place of the stock nut. Only requires drilling 2 holes.

Recommended method of installation - remove old motor and bolt adapter plate to printer using old motor screw locations. Note the adapter is "clocked" a little off...it doesn't line up with the cut out in the sheetmetal but it is accurate otherwise, i.e. cosmetic issue only. Use adapter to mark the locations for the new motor mounting points (uses only 2 screws, not all 4). Center punch and drill accurate hole locations. Mount new motor using screws coming in from the top. Attach leadscrew nut to the lower side of the carriage. The leadscrew needs to be 215mm long, measured from the front edge of the motor...give or take a few mm.

author: ScotY

description.text:
Drone model as nature would design it. After the topology optimization used other software for little details. For this model the best way to attach the electronics and battery to chassis will be a kind of rope or if the users will want a specific way to link the electronics I can prepare a 3D model special for that requisition.
I think that with a little bit of feedback I can make the model almost perfect.
-- For ABS Material the actual mass is 14.645 g
ACCORDING TO THE STRESS ANALYSIS
-- Maximum stress supported by the model is 0.86 MPa
-- Factor of Safety: 37.561 (I think it's a bit exaggerated)
-- Maximum Displacement: 12.642 micrometer (0,012642 mm)

During the setup of loads and constraints of the simulation it has been mandatory to choose at least one face to constrain, in spite of that in a real drone there is not a face or group of faces that are fixed. So the simulation may not represent a very realistic result. I tried different configuration but all the others gived me similar results. In another simulation software, the "bridge" that joins the "arms" of the motors may suffer buckling, but that results only come up with that particular software.

comments.text: First, I want to say I'm impressed with your design and I might be able to give some feedback on the overhang. I want to start off by saying I'm not an expert when it comes to CAD/CAM, but I know my way around and might be able to give some input. I'm not sure which software you are using, or how you are optimizing the structure; however, if you create a dummy part and run a draft analysis on the part to make sure there is nothing over a 60 degree overhang, then you can use that part, apply the loads and constraints and then optimize the structure to create a new part. The optimized structure might still have overhang over 60 degrees, but the amount of over hang and support material could be greatly reduced through this process.
comments.author: Computer_Aided_Design_Specialist

comments.text: Hello, thank you for your interest. The problem is that I don't know any way to find where are the overhangs but I though another way to print it. Instead of trying print it all at once, that will cause a big amount of support material, but we could split the model in half. What I mean is that you will print the bottom part first, that part where the motors and the electronics will sit on, and the second part which are the arms that support everything print it in a separate model oriented upwards. And glue it thotheter at the end. That will reduce the support material ver 90%
comments.author: Computer_Aided_Design_Specialist

comments.text:
Very nice. if you want to print this however, you need a lot of suport material.
I'm wondering if a similar structure can be derived with the additional constraint of minimizing any overhang of 60 degrees or more?
(even when positioned upside down, the little "landing pads" on the legs result in support material)

Ecco il file per realizzare una cover che permette di agganciare un obiettivo Nikon a un telefono Iphone 5S.

This is a straightforward remix of barspin's (aka Daniel Norée) famous 3d printable wrench, with as main goal making it less frustrating to print and get working. Things I changed in this remix:

  • The supports have a smaller contact area with the model at their undersides, and have larger clearances at their sides. The supports from the original model are very difficult to remove for no good reason, because they hug the model both at their top and underside. There is no reason to place the underside of the supports so close to the model, it only helps to get a nice finish on the supports themselves, which will be destroyed anyway.
  • I hollowed out the lower parts of the supports, so your printer doesn't spend time and filament on those parts if you print the wrench with a high infill.
  • The ridges on the jaw that match the wheel, are slanted because the ridges on the wheel are also slanted. This makes the wheel easier to turn and reduces the risk that these parts get fused during printing.
  • The tolerance on the wheel has been increased slightly so it will turn more easily.
  • I added 0.2 mm to the underside of the model, to allow to make the wheel more complete. I used the extra 0.2 mm to add a tiny raft. This makes the wheel easier to print and reduces the risk that the small ridges get knocked over during printing of the first few layers. You will need to carefully carve this raft with a sharp knife to get a nice round shape on the entire wheel.

I also provide a version of the wrench with the text removed, and you can use Customizer to add your own text. If you want to add text to the dual extrusion print, set ‘Dualstrusion’ to yes, and combine the model with the More_Printable_Wrench-dual-inserts.stl file in your slicer.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Printed with 3 perimeters, 4 bottom and 5 top solid layers for extra strength and a nice finish.
If you have a cooling fan, make sure it blows at full power while the jaw parts are being bridged across the main part, and vice versa.

Removing the supports will be a lot easier than on the original model. However, be prepared to still spend about an hour until you have either a working wrench, or a pile of broken plastic.

Despite the easier to remove supports, you still need to ensure that their smaller fragments are removed from the inside of the wrench as well. A sharp knife like an X-acto will be very helpful, and is essential as well to remove the mini-raft from the wheel. Try to carve the raft so you get a nice round shape on the ridges.

The most difficult thing is to get the jaw to move. The design is not very good in this regard, there simply is a large part where layers that are supposed to be disconnected, are printed on top of each other with no proper bridge attachment points. No matter how much clearance is provided, the filament will not simply hover in the air, it will drop down and especially PLA will have enough heat capacity to fuse with the underlying layers.

What seems to work reasonably well, is to shove a segment of disposable cutter blade in between the jaw and the rest, as shown on the photo. You can also wedge a screwdriver in between the gaps at the wheel. However, the way in which I eventually got my print to move, was to apply enough force on the jaw that the whole thing simply broke apart. This allowed me to smooth out the parts, after this I re-assembled it and repaired using ABS slurry as glue.

2017/05/23

Added dual extrusion models, and customizer to change the text.

2017/06/19

Fixed the broken customizer after a long and tedious battle against bugs in OpenSCAD/CGAL. Apparently it cannot handle combining polyhedra very well, so I resorted to just importing the model twice. As a side effect of my attempts to work around the bug, the model produced by customizer is now slightly cleaner than the original, but you probably won't notice this in normal prints.

2017/06/24

Optimized the Customizer file again so the workaround is no longer necessary, by further cleaning up the model.

title: VESA 100 flush wall mount for drywall

description.text:
This is a VESA 100mm flush wall mount for tv/monitor. I made 2 styles :

  • Type A : Requires only a hole in the wall, it has a 'hook' system.
  • Type B : Requires 8 screws to fix it in the wall, plus anchors or pieces of wood. It's usefull if you have something behind the wall wich prevents you to use the hook system.

You need to print :

  • 4x monitor pins
  • 1x plate (Type A or Type B)
  • For the type A plate only, you'll need 4 hooks too

You need these mounting hardware parts :

  • 4x M4x16mm countersunk screws to mount the pins at the back of the monitor
  • (Type A) 4x M4x16mm countersunk screws and 4x M4 nuts
  • (Type B) 9x screws (with drywall anchors, or a piece of wood behind the wall, as you want)

Instructions :

  • Make a hole 133,00 mm x 139,50 mm in the drywall (about 5 1/4" x 5 1/2")
  • Fix the plate in it with the 4 hooks + screws + nuts (Type A) or with the 8 screws (Type B)
  • Screw the 4 pins to the back of the monitor
  • Hang your monitor/tv on the wall plate

title: Amiga 1200 Gotek USB disk drive emulator base

description.text:
These items create a base for the well known Gotek USB disk drive emulators used in Amiga 1200 computers.
There is no need to cut the Amiga computer case, and the buttons and USB port can be accessed and used easily.
Also the disk drive button port will be covered so no hole is being left.

New updated version which supports FlashFloppy - Oled displays: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2788991

I've used Orange ABS filament from MakerPoint with temperature setting 250/90 deg. C (heaterblock/bed).
It takes about 5 hours to print and uses around 3.7 meter of filament at 50% infill and 0.1mm layer height.

Both items were created using OpenSCAD.

comments.text: My printer seems to be a having a hard time trying to form the 2 screw holes for the first few layers, then later on I get weird layer shifting just for the screw holes..  rest of the print is fine..   wondering if its an issue with Cura.  might try another slicer.   anyone else with the same issue ?
comments.author: gstandard

comments.text: I haven't seen this behaviour when printing this model. No idea where it comes from...
comments.author: gstandard

comments.text: I think its more due to my printer having issues with getting short runs of filament to stick. The walls of the screwholes are initially created independently, which are very quick short runs.  Im having issues laying down a skirt immediately, it doesnt seem to stick until 1/2 around the first run of the skirt.  I might try raising my bed a little or try different filament.
comments.author: _CrazyBob_

comments.text: I've bought a 'metric feeler gauge' from Ebay which I use for calibration of the bed level. (0.15mm) This improved printing the first layer.
comments.author: gstandard

comments.text: definitely was due to my nozzle being to far from bed.   Before I had to do initial layer of 0.3mm for success with other prints (a4 paper loosely touching nozzle) but now with paper moderately tight against nozzle I can print initial layer of 0.09mm.    Now I have it printing almost perfect..    yep I think I will grab the feeler gauge.   Its hard to get a feel for how close the nozzle should be to the bed with just paper.  I've just realised after 2 months I havent been doing it 100% right but other models print fine with my original 0.3mm initial layer height..   Took 7.5 hours to print at 0.1mm, cant wait to try it out tonight on the old a1200.. many thanks for the model!

description.text: This is Moineau (progressive cavity) pump, adapted to fit ZMorph carriage. It is designed to work with liquid chocolate or cake, which can be fed continuously through opening at the top. This way you can always control level of remaining material, and refill if necessary during normal operation. All parts are washable and easy do dismantle. It is recommended to print it with PLA (food friendly). Be sure not to wash it in dishwasher (too hot!). To see it in action check https://vimeo.com/82500516 for more info visit http://www.zmorph3d.com

To assemble, print all the parts (PLA), and get the vitamins :
  • stepper motor (NEMA 17)
  • flexible coupler - 5/8mm
  • M8 screw (about 40mm length)
  • 4 M3 screws (10mm) to mount the motor
  • 4 M4 screw (20mm) to put two biggest parts together
  • optional four M4 screws to secure the motor on top of the container
  • one M4x40 screw and nut to mount everything to ZMorph carriage
    (check our other things, it's downloadable from Thingiverse too)
    • It's pretty easy to assemble everything, just use attached image as guidance.

comments.text:
It is the basic design , the way a progressive cavity pump works.
The core of the stator needs to be a heavy elastomer , such as (Alumilite High Strength 3 RTV silicone).
With out a flexible inner core the rotor will not seal. If you would like , I can take a pic of a core ant the building mold used to make it.

I needed this part for my old W126 Mercedes, as without it the sunroof keeps getting out of adjustment and causing it to not operate properly. This part is very hard to come across by itself. My local Mercedes dealer said they could order me one, but it would cost over 70 dollars and it had to be shipped special order from Germany!

This is why I designed this relatively simple model to help any fellow owners out if their part gets broken or lost.
Now this piece should work right off of the printer, no modification necessary.

description.text:
~~~ You might also want to consider my Universal Spool Hub Adapter. ~~~

I use filaments from many different manufacturers, and was disappointed when they all used different spool sizes/widths. I have a Flashforge Dreamer and am using @BaronWilliams' OmniStands with relish, and so decided to come up with an OpenSCAD-designed spool adapter that lets you set the adapter dimensions so you can make a compatible hub.

The modifiable parameters include:

  • Height (length) of the adapter
  • Outer diameter (width) of the adapter
  • Inner diameter (width) of the axle
  • Number of spokes

BaronWilliams' OmniStands:
Top Mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:704631
Internal Side Mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:652415

The OpenSCAD design makes use of the Arc module created by T3P3 and available under GPLv3 license: http://www.youmagine.com/designs/4765

title: TAYRONA 360: Universal Panohead for all mobile models + Street View Google

description.text:
La TAYRONA 360 es una rótula panorámica que permite hacer fotografías 360 esféricas con cualquier celular que soporte giroscopio. Funciona perfectamente con la aplicación Street View de Google.

Las fotos quedan perfectas, sin errores de costura. Tayrona 360 es el complemento ideal de Google Street View y una gran herramienta para los Local Guides de Google.

Es universal, gracias a su sistema de anclaje, lo que permite adaptarse a cualquier tamaño de celular y posición de la cámara. Es robusta, resistente, muy práctica, liviana y bella.

Licencia

Los planos de esta rótula están licenciados con Creative Commons Reconocimiento. Esto quiere decir que puedes descargar los planos y hacer tu rótula para ti o para otros. Si deseas comercializarla en tu país, SÍ lo puedes hacer, legalmente. Lo único que solicitamos es que mantengas el nombre TAYRONA 360 y no se lo cambies.

En otras palabras, tienes todo el derecho de comercializarla en tu país.

Comunidad y soporte

En nuestro Grupo de Usuarios de Tayrona 360 de Facebook, encontrará ejemplos reales de fotos esféricas tomadas con diferentes dispositivos.

Si necesitas soporte, te invitamos a entrar a Kamaradas, la comunidad de panoramistas de habla hispana.

+++++++

Agradecimientos especiales a todas las personas que colaboran en la elaboración de esta rótula:

  • Mario Carvajal: creador de la idea
  • David Gómez de 3GH: prototipo en 3D
  • Jonhatan Pedraza: prototipo inicial de rótula en acrílico
  • Y todos los demás que empiecen a aportar a partir de ahora.

+++++++++=

title: Subaru Impreza 2015 Cupholder lift
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I always order small size drinks at McDonalds and the cup holders between the driver and front passenger in my 2015 Subaru Impreza are too deep for them. In a pinch I could buffer the space with napkins or whatever else was lying around, but since I have a 3d printer I figured I should just fix this once and for all.

There are two sizes here because the two cup holders have different depths. The front one is deeper, so I had to make a taller lift for that one.

I only own an Impreza so I couldn't test this on other Subarus, but it's possible it would work in others if the cup holder design is the same.

A filament spool hanger designed to mount on the edge of a shelf - it can be used just to store your filament, or if the shelf is close by you can feed your printer directly from the spools where they hang. I wanted to keep it simple, flexible, and 100% printable - no metal parts are required (bearings, rods, etc.). But if you want to combine some metal parts into your implementation these hangers will work with that too. The STLs included here are sized to fit the shelf above my printer, but the design is fully parametric so you can use the Thingiverse Customizer to fit them to whatever size shelf and spools you happen to have, within the limits of your printer of course.

There are 5 separate components all potentially generated from the single design - I recommend letting the customizer generate all of the ones you need together to ensure they are all compatible, and then using your slicing software to separate them for making multiple copies of some, or printing different parts with different settings.

If you would like to see additional mount options for the top part of the hanger, please leave me a comment describing it. I'm currently considering doing options for screwing it to a horizontal or vertial surface, or to clamp around a piece of extrusion.

I've left it tagged as a work in progess for now, although at least for my needs I consider it finished. But I haven't tested every combination of odd parameters that people might want to use and its possible that some combination will cause a bug. Once I've seen a bunch of other customized versions go through and have more confidence I will remove the tag.

List of included parts

The Clamp

The clamp is the main part, designed to slide over the edge of a shelf and hang down with a hook at the bottom - you will need at least two of them (one on each end of a rod). The hook at the bottom is sized to grab a rod of the configured diameter, but in my testing these clamps are strong enough that if you used a longer non-printed rod (say a metal threaded rod) you could easily hang 10+ spools from just a single pair of hangers. Regardless of what kind of rod you plan to use - entering the correct dimension in the customizer will ensure that the hooks get a good grip on it. For my use, I printed the clamps in PETG, at 0.2mm layers, 3 perimiters, and 20% infill - and I can pull with all my strength and cannot break them with pulling force alone.

The Screw

The screw part is designed to thread through the bottom of the clamp, and clamp it against the shelf. Not much else to say about it. I had a few minor issues with snapping them, and so printed them at 90% infill, but otherwize the same settings as the clamps. For a better grip on the shelf, I also printed mine with a filament-change 3 layers before the top, doing the top three layers in a flexible filament to be squeezed against the shelf.

The Rod

The rod again is very simple - just a rod. The default diameter of 16mm matches the size of the studs on the stock Prusa Original i3 MK2 spool holders, and also the size of the cups on my modified MK2 spool holders, so I kept that size here too so that I could re-use my existing rods. I print them at 0.35mm thick layers and with a 10mm brim, keeping the 3 perimiters and 20% infill as the clamp. I recommend making these as tall as your printer is capable of printing. Or as an option use a metal or wood rod to go even longer - just remember to still set the customizer for the correct diameter as it is also used in the hook on the clamp part.

Optional: The Gasket

The gasket is a single-layer-thick (0.2mm) square of material sized to fit inside the clamp - its purpose it to help give the clamp better grip on the shelf. I print these out of flexible material and then superglue it under the top of the clamp, so that the weight presses it down onto the shelf. If you find your clamps slide too easily on your shelves you can use these, or can use any other high-friction material to stuff in there - I've also used paper-towel folded over a few times which is also quite effective.

Optional: The Test

The test object is just a threaded nut, where the threads have exactly the same parameters as the threads in the bottom of the clamp. If you are customizing the screw and want to test if your threads will work without having to print an entire clamp, you can save some time and plastic by printing the test object. It has no other purpose and is not designed to be used in the final assembled clamp. For accurate testing, print it with the same settings you intend to use for your clamp, and leave it oriented as it is. The clamp threads will be printed at that orientation where the overhang/bridging at the top can cause issues with the threads, which is the primary thing that needs to be caught in testing.
ESTANTERÍA PARA MADERA 10 MM

This is a mount for the faceplate of a Yaesu FTM-100D that is custom fit for a 2014 Toyota Tundra. The metal faceplate mount that comes with the radio - bolts to this. There is a small gap in the Tundra console that the mount slides into in such a way that the console lid holds everything in place with out any screws or two-sided tape. It can be removed simply by opening the console lid. When mounted it doesn't interfere with the shifter or access to the the drink holders.
It holds the screen at the right angle and keeps the controls at your fingertips. The main part of the radio is under the drivers seat. The whole radio can be removed in less that 30 seconds with out any tools. No permanent modification to the Tundra is required.

A generic PCB clamp that uses an M4 bolt to clamp down onto the edge of the PCB, so tiny PCBs with no mounting holes can be held in place.
Alternatively, if there is a mounting hole, just use it as a spacer!

Clean excess plastic out of the slot, position the clamp so tat it grips a couple of mm of the edge of the boad. Mark the base, drill an M4 hole, put a washer on top and another underneath transfixed with M4 bolt. Nut it up, and the pressure of the nutting grips the PCB.

A 3D model of U.S. Pat. No. 5,016,559. Cutting edge 1989 bookmark / pen holder technology from the original Thingiverse--the U.S. PTO.  
"The combination bookmark and writing instrument holder includes a generally planar marking strip and an integrally molded retaining clip at one end of the marking strip.  In the preferred embodiment, the retaining clip includes a pair of generally symmetrical, outwardly jaws that together present a writing instrument retaining channel.  The channel includes a writing instrument retaining portion, and an outwardly flared mouth portion for guiding the writing instrument into the retaining portion."

title: Anet A8 Supported Filament Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I looked at all of the printer filament holder brackets that I could find for the A8. There are some effective ones, but most of them seem to mount on the flimsiest part of the printer. Many people complain that their filament brackets warp the printer frame and make the bed unleveled. These either mount on the display lexan edge, the display screws, or some other weak location. If they do mount on a strong location, it's a weird orientation like sideways mounting and the like. There could be something out there that is better that I missed, but my intention with this design was to mount the filament bracket on the strongest part of the top of the printer. It mounts directly onto the two vertical members of the printer frame and actually reinforces the joint. I designed this setup to work with 3/8"-16 threaded rod. If you place the nuts in the orientation in the first picture, you will be able to quick release the spool. Because this is a structural horizontal rod mount, the possibility is there to mount multiple filament reels on the printer at the same time. PLEASE NOTE THE PRINT SETTING REQUIREMENTS BELOW. You will need to change out the 3mm x 16mm frame screws included with the printer to 3mm x 20mm long screws, in order to attach the members to the printer frame. If you have a frame stabilizer printed and mounted to the front of the printer, you mind as well remove them as they don't seem to work well as frame stabilizers anyway! If you want a frame stabilizer, this one is fantastic and actually works: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1872162 Enjoy what I have so far...and if you make this, don't be lazy and take a picture and post it on here!

UPDATE

Height extender added. I found out that some discount spools are larger in diameter than standard spools. You also might want to run a spool without a center hub. As a result, I created an optional height extender to raise the spools even higher. Simply print this extender and place them on top of the existing brackets.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I printed the uprights with .3mm layer height, 4 shells on all sides, 30% rectangular grid infill. 4000 mm/min. On the spool hub adapter, the adapter has two STLs. One STL must be printed in a particular direction (see close-up photos of layers). The simple side (the one with the 6 spokes) can be printed with no supports, where the hole axis is vertical to the print bed. I used 40% infill, 3 shells on all sides and .3mm layer height. On the side with the 4 spokes and the locking tabs, this unit MUST be printed with the hole axis HORIZONTAL to the print bed, with similar print settings. I found out that in printing this part horizontally you will need both a raft and support structure all around. THIS IS A PAIN TO PRINT BUT IS REQUIRED because if you print this part vertically like the other side, the tabs will immediately break on first connection, as the layers will separate. The tabs get compressed during the mating/locking of the two sides. You will need two filament rod arms and as many sets of Filament Spool Adapters as you have spools. If you don't like my spool adapter solution and just want to use the uprights, I am sure that there a hundreds more spool adapters available on thingiverse!

UPDATE

Print the extenders WITH SUPPORTS, long edge horizontal to table at .2mm height, 40% infill.
Fusion 360 Rulez!

title: Anet A8 Right Side 12mm Inductive Sensor Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a work in progress...I was looking for a sensor bracket for the A8 in order to add auto-levelling firmware to my setup. Most of the brackets that I have found either mount on the left side of the extruder using the heat sink screws or on the weak spot on the front fan screws. I noticed that people that print entirely new carriages for the X-Axis have the sensor mounted on the right side. I figured that I could add a sensor to the right side mounting block screws, so I made up this little bracket to go on a standard setup. It accommodates a 12mm diameter threaded inductive sensor. I still have to look at the Skynet firmware to see if the probe locations on the table have a sensor position offset, so if it does this design will be able to be used. Please provide feedback if this design was useful and how you handled the firmware.

title: Qidi Avatar heat chamber for ABS

description.text:
A heat chamber to keep the build area warm and as less ventilated as possible.

Since I usually print ABS I decided to close the existing gap on the backside of the acrylic cover structure that's on top of the printer. Since filament and cables are fed in though the back I had the extend to cover accordingly. The back is closed by two printed part (sideA and sideB), plus an extra overhead transparency (DIN A4, other sizes might fit as well) that are all glued to the acrylic cover.
Both sides are very thin, i.e. usually they should print transparent with the lattice and logo clearly visible.

And I also added a bridge to support the filament supply (avoiding that is pulled down too much and then collides with the sides of the acrylic structure moving it around with loud noise during printing).

Designed in IceSL and Cura (3D logo creation)

Printer:

Qidi Avatar IV

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

No

Notes:

Printed in ABS. It's a big part, but there shouldn't be any warping, mainly because it's not high at all.

Get an not too thick transparency in the size of a DIN A4 sheet in portrait mode, and glue it to the two parts and then glue everything to the existing acrylic cover.
Start with one side, then do the other and only then move on to glue it to the acrylic cover. I used white glue for it. That worked fine, and while it took a long time to dry it is almost transparent now. Hot glue might work as well.

The bridge must not be glued! It should really be removable.

QX06 Pegboard Ashtray with Snuffers

This is my first entry into my PEGBOARD MADNESS collection of designs.

The PEGBOARD MADNESS concept consists of a modular male pegboard adaptor that various objects can be adapted to. I’ve included STEP files of the objects created here so that you can modify and adapt to your liking, or incorporate into your own design. Please let me know if you do! I’d love to see them!

I’m giving a REMIX SHOUT OUT to “variador” and the “AC Adaptor Organizer” that was uploaded. Of all the pegs that I’ve designed or downloaded, Variador’s method has proved the best all-around so far. I re-designed them in Fusion 360 so they can be manipulated easier – for me, anyway – in a CAD environment.

This ashtray was designed to be aesthetically pleasing, and the design process was simply two profile sketches on the X/Z plane swept along a sketched path on the XY plane. If you use Fusion 360 and you would be interested in joining that project, let me know. I’ve never done it before, but I’d be interested in trying this form of collaboration and exploration.

This ashtray STL was sliced and coded using ReplicatorG employing 2 shells (3 total) using PLA.

  • FlashForge Creator Pro (Similar to Makerbot Replicator 2)
  • Custom Profile that allows supports without rafts
  • Heated Bed 45 Celsius
  • Blue Painters Tape on bed, no further treatment
  • Print Temperature 220 degrees Celsius
  • Feedrate 40 mm/s
  • Travel Feedrate 55
    (If anybody has more optimum feedrates, please share!)

The Male Pegboard Adaptor was printed with CLEAR PET. I used the exact same settings as I do for PLA, and it works well.

SMOKE ‘EM IF YA GOTTEM!

title: Empanadilla Maker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple Empanadilla Maker (turnover maker). Empanadillas, also known in Puerto Rico as empanadas or pastelillos, are baked or fried pastries. Here in Puerto Rico we eat them stuffed with a lot of things, like meat, chicken, pizza sauce and cheese, guava paste, shrimp... you name it. The are really good! This little device is used to fold the empanadilla and close the seam. Since the PLA I used may not be the safest, I use the same paper that separates the pastry to fold them, avoiding the food from touching the plastic. Just in case... That also keeps it clean.

You will ned two 5mm screws for the hinge. You may want to print some plastic screws for this. The hinge does not take too much load.

print_settings.Notes:: Print with 3 perimeter layers to increase the likelihood of an airtight seal. Proper layer bonding is critical to avoid rattles or buzzing sounds in the future.

description.text:
An angular speaker enclosure for 3 in speaker drivers.

Printed in two pieces, top/front and bottom/back. Then sealed together with epoxy after speaker and binding posts are mounted internally.

The internal of the enclosure features additional angular panels to help reduce the standing wave effect of sound bouncing off the flat back wall. Some say this is not a real concern, (and it certainly shouldn't be on a small speaker like this,) but hey it looks cool, it might help in some way, and I like it!

I printed mine in PLA, though ABS and PETG should work just as well.

Hatchbox Wood for the top/front and eSun Warm White for the bottom/back. Printed in 0.3mm layer height for both pieces because I liked the inconsistent, heavy layered look of the wood filament for this project.

Printer:

Custom Kossel Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print with 3 perimeter layers to increase the likelihood of an airtight seal. Proper layer bonding is critical to avoid rattles or buzzing sounds in the future.

Clean Up

You may need to (or wish to) do some light sanding and filing on the inside section of the speaker cutout. Note that this part prints upside-down, so any overhang nastiness will be visible in the bottom of the speaker hole when assembled.

Mount Hardware

Use the 4 3M screws to attach the speaker to the front of the case from the inside. If you choose to use nylon washers, those will be implemented here to keep the metal of the screw heads from contacting the speaker casing.

Mount the binding post terminal in the back through the two holes. You will only need the front plastic piece, one lock washer on each side, and two nuts on each side if you are using the parts linked below.

Wiring

Solder speaker wire to the speaker terminals. Cut to an appropriate length so you can still open the case enough to tighten the nuts on the binding post terminals. Attach each wire to the appropriate binding post terminal.

This would be an excellent time to test the wiring and speaker. After the case is glued together in the next step, there will be no going back to fix things in a non-destructive way.

Glue

Apply glue to the inside track of the bottom piece and along the shelf that faces towards the front. Be careful not to pull on your wiring or drip glue on the outside of the speaker enclosure.

Lightly clamp the two pieces together while they dry. I simply used some masking tape in place of clamps and it worked well.

3in Speaker Driver

2 Needed

http://www.ebay.com/itm/172123969777?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

The speakers at the link above are the one's I used and can confirm fit well (and sound pretty great considering the price!) You do not have to use those, any standard 3in speaker should fit as well.

Speaker Terminal Binding Post

2 Needed

https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B01DLXQ15A/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

They tend to difficult to find or expensive to buy in quantities smaller than 10 pieces.

Screws

4 x 8mm 3M screws

4 x 3M nylon washers (optional)

Wire

Any wire suitable for speakers will do. A very small amount is needed, less than 1 ft.

Glue

You will need some kind of glue to seal the two halve together. These speakers are not intended to come apart once assembled (so be sure your connections are solid internally before sealing.)

Any epoxy or other glue with good "gap-filling" properties will work well. We need the gap filling ability to help maintain a good seal where layer lines meet at the seam.

title: Spoolholder for CTC Bizer (and other Replicator clones)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After gathering some ideas around here, I designed my own spoolholder where the spool rests on 608ZZ bearings. Easy to load and very smooth in supplying filament to the extruder.
Design is for spools with total width of around 70 mm. If needed I can add bars for other size spools or even an adjustable version. When you want something, just leave a comment.

Update (Feb.12/'17):
Since there are different size spools I created some parts that make the whole design adjustable in width. With the adjustable bars you can go up to 110 mm wide spools. You need the two bars and 8 adjustment clamps. These are designed to be fixed in place using M3x10mm (>8mm) and square M3 nuts (DIN562). Since I only have one size spools, I haven't made these parts yet.

Printer:

CTC Bizer Dual

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

<=50% & 100%

Notes:

Both bars I have printed with 100% infill. The supports parts I printed at 50%. You might easily get away with less.
I've done my prints in PETG using Simplify3D @ 65mm/sec

I used 4 bearings type 608ZZ (outside diameter 22 mm, inside diameter 8mm, thickness 7mm)
Design has small holes where you can use a small screw to press material out to clamp bearing. So far, I didn't need it, it was tight enough.

comments.text: So far, no problems. Bearings run smooth so will not come off easily. You just have to be carefull you don't bump into the spool so it might tilt. It will not fall off easily though. When that happens, it will need a bit more force to roll off.

author: R3mi

description.text:
To aid in its planned conquest of Syracusan worlds, the Dominion would of course need to land its troops, as quickly and efficiently as possible. The result was the Mark 15 Starspike, a truly unique aircraft in that it was never designed to land. The ship would be launched with disposable booster rockets on the proper trajectory towards a planet. When it encountered the atmosphere, the massive saucer on its front end would act as a combination of airfoil and ablative panel, allowing the craft to cruise at extremely high altitudes towards its destination. The four massive jet engines mounted on the rear of the craft kept its speed up. The result was a craft that flew only partly on aerodynamic wings, and partly by skipping of the surface tension of the upper atmosphere.
When over the landing zone, the saucer would detach from the rest of the body, falling to the planet's surface and allowing Dominion troops to disembark. The rest of the craft, freed from its load, would return to a low orbit, where it could be picked up and returned to its mothership. The advantage of this system over conventional reentry vehicles was the much higher speeds and maneuverability it could maintain over its run, as well as its higher level of reusability.

Vibration Damper for Anet A8

This is a remix of the popular vibration damper from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:91720 .
This has been customized for the Anet A8, by introducing a 8mm slot that fits the acrylic frame.
For those of us that have printed reinforcements for front or back plates, I've added 2 special corner versions (one for the left side and another for the right side).

For each of the dampers, you should always print a pairing Damper Helper. This is the part that goes inside the damper and is the same for all 3 versions.

title: Simple tube system for the Drawing machine

description.text:
These tubes prevent the BYJ48 cables from getting between and around the moving parts of the machine. You first have to extend the cables with some soldering and heat-shrink tubing. Aim long at first: approximatively X + Y + 40 cm.

I picked 7.5mm and 6.5mm Ø tubes but feel free to adjust the models to your need (I added FreeCAD files if you use that, else go with the STLs).

The orientation of the stl files is not convenient for printing, orient them correctly before!

In order:

1) Cut the BYJ48 cable socket so that you only have 5 bare cables.

2) Extend the cables with some of your own by soldering and isolating with heat-shrink tubing.

3) Thread the first tube (Y axis) on the cables

4) Pass the cables through the top of the left column of the heart-shaped part and back up the through the right one (see the picture). Remove the two bottom-left screws of the central moving part of the machine (when looking from the back, see the picture) and screw the heart-shaped part with slightly longer screws. You can put a temporary screw from the bottom while you remove the two first in order for the pulley not to go away.

5) Thread the second tube (X Axis) on the cables

6) Again, replace two screws of either NEMA motor with slightly longer screws after placing the smoking pipe shaped part.

The magnifying glass is held in by a thin walled, lipped bushing. If you tend to grab and twist on the front of the lamp, like most people, you can crack the ring. Then the glass falls out. I tried gluing it (Go E6000!!) but it soon cracked again.

Here's a replacement ring....it should fit on several versions. While the lamps look different the maganifying glass and attachment ring are just slightly varied. You may have to scale it up or down. I suggest printed the first few layers and removing what's on there to verify the scale. Adjust if needed and reprint it.

Don't monkey tighten this down. I think that's why the first one broke. It needs a little flex..or a total redesign to make it much beefier....Hmmm.....might do that.

print_settings.Notes:: If you set the corner radius too big, you'll have almost no contact area on the bed, which may result in failed prints as the lobes peel off. Try sizing it as no more than half of the weight rim value.

title: Parametric Fidget Spinner for Growler Tokens

description.text:
I wanted to use the growler fill tokens from a local brewery (Phillips in Victoria, BC) but couldn't find a parametric spinner that would let me use different sized weights instead of just identical bearings. I may have slightly missed the bandwagon on this one, but I think this is a cool way to incorporate any token or coin to a fidget spinner.

This design allows as many weights (lobes) as you want, with adjustable thicknesses and diameters of both the weights and center bearing. It's currently sized for a 608ZZ bearing and dual tokens on each end. I plan to add caps for the bearing, as the tokens are quite large. I've got big hands, but for people who are more towards the Trump end of the hand size scale it could be difficult to hold.

There are some OpenSCAD renderings of different configurations (number of lobes, with and without the decorative holes) in the images, but the only real limit is the size of your hands, the size of your print bed, and Euclidian geometry!

I used Robo's rounded cylinders for the outer edges, and standard cylinders for the cutouts.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58478

Printer:

D-Bot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

If you set the corner radius too big, you'll have almost no contact area on the bed, which may result in failed prints as the lobes peel off. Try sizing it as no more than half of the weight rim value.

title: Tevo Black Widow Controlbox vertical mounting to profile

description.text:
The original Black Widow control box is large and in some appliications not user friendly.

I took the PSU as a seperate part and placed it elsewhere (underneath the printer table). The MKS GEN V1.4 and the PSU are connected by 12 AWG silicone wire and XT60 connectors to make them easy disconnectable. Mounting bracket is included.

The MKS GEN V1.4 mainboard is equipped with an angled USB adapter cable where the end is hot glued in the controlbox.
The original 120 mm control box fan is reused and part of the construction and cools the MKS GEN v1.4 adequat. The 24 volt fan is stepped down by a 24 to 12 volt DC/DC converter. Cables and other wires can be tightend to the box by zipties. 6 bridges can be used.

The controlpanel can be moved at the required location on the vertical profile.
SD card is still accessable.

If you use a raspberry Pi there is a holder for it too.

Can be printed in your beloved filament except Flex/TPU

Nozzle size used 0.4 mm at 0.2 mm layerheigth.
Infill 25 %

Controlbox is a 16 hour print!

Hardware needed
M4 x 10mm hex screws (8) for profile mounting
M4 T nuts (8) for profile mounting
M3 x 35 MM hex screws (4) for fan
XT60 connector (1 pair - male/female) for 24 volt power cable
Zipties 3 mm width (10) to cable up the wires
1meter 14 AWG silicone cable red/black
1 x angled USB A/B adapter cable

Printer:

Tevo Black Widow

RHS means rigth hand side.

description.text:
This is not so much a remix but it is a ground up redesign of Aldwin's antweight bot called plover. All parts will now print without support and there is slightly more useable space inside for the electronics to fit.
The lid is no longer held on with screws but is now held on by friction and the little nubs on the pillars of the lid, This means that the battery connector can be used as the isolator and there is no longer any need for a switch. The receiver and esc's I use have led's on them and are easily seen through the plastic so there is no need for a separate power led either.
Also the slight increase in space inside the bot has allowed to more easily use a 260mah battery pack and as you can see in the photo there is enough space to go even bigger than 260mah if you wish to.
Weight wise my complete bot comes in at around 120gm, could save a bit by tidying up the wireing aswell so it is possible to print with higher infill than i did.

Printer:

CTC Replicator Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I have printed all the parts in PLA, ABS and PC-ABS and Taulman Alloy 910 to see which holds up better though i expect in this application they should all hold up fairly well. PLA probably not as well as the others if it comes up against a spinning weapon.
Post-Print required no cleanup for me with any of the materials, You'r mileage may vary however.

comments.text: Great work, that's a very clever redesign, I love how the lid now attaches!

print_settings.Notes:: Something about either the bearing cap model or the way Cura sliced it for me, but the jerk control fails to work, which makes the Y-axis timing belt on my Prusa i3 to skip. I found that setting the speed on the printer itself to 40% kept it from messing up. At 75% I could raise the speed up to 75% to finish the print a bit faster. The other options of course are to use someone else's cap designs or not to use caps at all, but I recommend using them for comfort and ease of use.

description.text: I couldn't find an unbalanced fidget spinner on Thingiverse that was what I was looking for, so I made my own. It features a "keyring" on one side and a bearing on the other of the central bearing. This imbalance allows the user to move it in many different ways (see additional photos).

Printer:

Hictop Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2-0.25mm for both parts

Infill:

15-30% for both parts

Notes:

You need to print out 1 frame and 4 bearing caps. I suggest laying out all four (spares too if desired) in your slicer to help with cooling.

PLA recommended

Something about either the bearing cap model or the way Cura sliced it for me, but the jerk control fails to work, which makes the Y-axis timing belt on my Prusa i3 to skip. I found that setting the speed on the printer itself to 40% kept it from messing up. At 75% I could raise the speed up to 75% to finish the print a bit faster. The other options of course are to use someone else's cap designs or not to use caps at all, but I recommend using them for comfort and ease of use.

Assembly

This design calls for two 608ZZ size* bearings, medium grit sandpaper and a pair of pliers.
1) Using a strip of medium grit sand paper, smooth out the round-edged hole for comfort.
2) Press each of the bearings into the other two holes, then use pliers to force the EDGES of the bearing flush with the frame. If you crush the metal between the inner and outer rings, the bearing may fail to spin properly.
3) Push the caps into the bearings. It should be a bit difficult, but if they don't quite fit, sand the edges of the triangles until they do.

*NOTE: I'm not quite sure how bearing sizing works (608 vs 608Z, etc.), so if you aren't sure either, this spinner is designed specifically for "608ZZ" bearings.
Here's an Amazon link to the ones I bought (they're pretty cheap, but they work way better than the ones I cannibalized from an old skateboard):
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBD6X4/

comments.text: I tried printing this, but the holes were to large for 608* bearings (slides right through the hole).  I like the design, so I'll either attempt to scale it down, or just recreate it.

description.text:
This is another wall bracket for the Echo Dot (Generation 1). The difference is that this bracket maintains the horizontal orientation of the 6 microphones -- the renderings show the bracket on its side. Granted you'll only be getting 180 degrees pickup, but that may still improve the mic performance.

There are two cutouts on the back side so you can run the power and speaker cords from one side or the other with clearance for the plug bodies.

The difference between the two is the width of the mounting plates -- 95mm or 50mm. I made the 95mm first for flat walls and then the 50mm to mount on the side of a bed's headboard.

I print this model on its "back" (as shown) and use supports.
